infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian

Class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian.MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
extends MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
implements MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, java.lang.Cloneable

    Computes the differential mutual information of two given multivariate double[][] sets of observations (implementing MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate), assuming that the probability distribution function for these observations is a multivariate Gaussian distribution.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian().
    • The user can call setCovariance(double[][], boolean) or setCovariance(double[][], int) or setCovarianceAndMeans(double[][], double[], int) instead of supplying observations via MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc.
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!
    • Additional method computeSignificance() to compute null distribution analytically.

    References:

    • T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Mathworld, Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Wikipedia, Multivariate normal distribution on Wikipedia

    • Field Detail

      • L

        protected double[][] L
        Cached Cholesky decomposition of the covariance matrix of the most recently supplied observations. Is a matrix [C_ss, C_sd; C_ds, C_dd], where C_ss is the covariance matrix of the source observations, C_dd is the covariance matrix of the destination observations, and C_sd and C_ds are the covariances of source to destination and destination to source observations. The covariance matrix is symmetric, and should be positive definite (otherwise we have linealy dependent variables).

      • Lsource

        protected double[][] Lsource
        Cached Cholesky decomposition of the source covariance matrix

      • Ldest

        Cached Cholesky decomposition of the destination covariance matrix

      • finaliseAddObservations

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from class: MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.

        This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.sourceObservations and MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.destObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.

        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Overrides:
        finaliseAddObservations in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the observation variables are not linearly independent (leading to a non-positive definite covariance matrix).

      • setCovariance

        public void setCovariance(double[][] covariance,
                 int numObservations)
                   throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the mutual information.

        This is an alternative to sequences of calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc. Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

        Parameters:
        covariance - covariance matrix of the source and destination variables, considered together (variable indices start with the source and continue into the destination). I.e. it is a matrix [C_ss, C_sd; C_ds, C_dd], where C_ss is the covariance matrix of the source observations, C_dd is the covariance matrix of the destination observations, and C_sd and C_ds are the covariances of source to destination and destination to source observations.
        numObservations - the number of observations that the covariance was determined from. This is used for later significance calculations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

      • setCovariance

        protected void setCovariance(double[][] covariance,
                 boolean determinedFromObservations)
                      throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the mutual information.

        This is an alternative to sequences of calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc. Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

        Parameters:
        covariance - covariance matrix of the source and destination variables, considered jointly together (variable indices start with the source and continue into the destination).
        determinedFromObservations - whether the covariance matrix was determined internally from observations or not
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

      • setCovarianceAndMeans

        public void setCovarianceAndMeans(double[][] covariance,
                         double[] means,
                         int numObservations)
                           throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the mutual information.

        This is an alternative to sequences of calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) or MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc. Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call computeLocalOfPreviousObservations().

        Parameters:
        covariance - covariance matrix of the source and destination variables, considered together (variable indices start with the source and continue into the destination).
        means - mean of the source and destination variables (as per covariance)
        numObservations - the number of observations that the mean and covariance were determined from. This is used for later significance calculations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the MI from the supplied observations or covariances.

        The joint entropy for a multivariate Gaussian-distribution of dimension n with covariance matrix C is -0.5*\log_e{(2*pi*e)^n*|det(C)|}, where det() is the matrix determinant of C.

        Here we compute the mutual information from the joint entropies of the source variables (H_s), destination variables (H_d), and all variables taken together (H_sd), giving MI = H_s + H_d - H_sd. We assume that the recorded estimation of the covariance is correct (i.e. we will not make a bias correction for limited observations here).

        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the MI of the previously provided observations or from the supplied covariance matrix, in nats (not bits!). Returns NaN if any of the determinants are zero (because this will make the denominator of the log 0).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the MI, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        If the user supplied covariance matrices rather than observations then this method cannot be called.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local MIs in nats (not bits!)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
        Generate an analytic distribution of what the MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that our variables had no relation. This is performed without bootstrapping (which is done in MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int) and MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int[][])).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below, and the other papers referenced in AnalyticNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance() (in particular Brillinger and Geweke), for a description of how this is done for MI. Basically, the null distribution is a chi-square distribution with degrees of freedom equal to the product of the number of variables in each joint variable 1 and 2.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution object which describes the proportion of MI scores from the null distribution which have higher or equal MIs to our actual value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from class: MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]), MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.addObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (i.e. where a MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF is set).

        Specified by:
        getNumObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Overrides:
        getNumObservations in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the user did not set observations but set covariance matrices instead.

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int[] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from class: MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

        Compute the mutual information if the first (source) variable were ordered as per the ordering specified in newOrdering.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using #addObservations(double[]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of a shuffled source series here.

        This method is primarily intended for use in MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.computeSignificance(int[][]) however has been made public in case users wish to access it.

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Child implementations must only over-write lastAverage if newOrdering is null, which indicates that the original ordering should be used (making this equivalent to a call to ChannelCalculatorCommon.computeAverageLocalOfObservations()).

        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Overrides:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in class MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
        Parameters:
        newOrdering - a specification of how to shuffle the source values to create a surrogate source time series. It is an array of length N (where would be the value returned by MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the MI under the new ordering, in nats (not bits!). Returns NaN if any of the determinants are zero (because this will make the denominator of the log 0).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the user previously supplied covariance directly rather than by setting observations (this means we have no observations to reorder).

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] newSourceObs,
                                             double[][] newDestObs)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        newSourceObs - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number)
        newDestObs - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index then variable number) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the local values in nats (not bits). If the MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF property was set to say k, then the local values align with the destination value (i.e. after the given delay k). As such, the first k values of the array will be zeros.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if means were not defined by supplying observations (eg via MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc) or calling #setCovarianceAndMeans(double[][], double[])

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        protected double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] newSourceObs,
                                             double[][] newDestObs,
                                             boolean isPreviousObservations)
                                                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Protected utility function to compute the local MI values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObs and newDestObs.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations. isPreviousObservations indicates whether those in states1 and states2 were some of the previously supplied samples.

        Parameters:
        newSourceObs - provided source observations
        newDestObs - provided destination observations
        isPreviousObservations - whether these are our previous observations - this determines whether to add zeros for the first timeDiff local values, and also whether to set the internal lastAverage field, which is returned by later calls to MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.getLastAverage()
        Returns:
        the local values in nats (not bits). If the MutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.PROP_TIME_DIFF property was set to say k, then the local values align with the destination value (i.e. after the given delay k). As such, the first k values of the array will be zeros.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if means were not defined by supplying observations (eg via MutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.setObservations(double[][], double[][]) etc) or calling #setCovarianceAndMeans(double[][], double[])
        See Also:
        Multivariate normal distribution on Wikipedia,
